Suddenly, the brows are free of profit’s shackles,
Why fear the body’s bonds of fame?
Once a pampered son of the household,
Now a man who has left his home.
At this point, ever at ease in the distance,
What matter the babble of words?

**Gifting Fellow Daoist Companions**
Where does cultivation require effort?
Swiftly sever the laggard horse and mad ape.
Firmly grasp, firmly seize—let the five colors arise,
Momentarily pause, momentarily stay—avoid the three paths.
A slight indulgence leaks the elixir of spirit,
A brief laxity withers the jade nature.
If wine, sex, anger, and wealth still linger in the heart,
Attaining the mysterious and wondrous is as if nothing.

**Again**
Though the Daoist lacks wealth, sex, and wine,
How to remove that single spark of ignorance?
When evil thoughts do not arise, return to purity,
When provoked, do not contend—realize the primordial.
Where self and others begin, sorrow knows no end,
When smoke and fire fade, joy remains.
To learn immortality, one must endure humiliation—
Do not let that true suchness burn away.

**Upon Hearing a Hometown Person Arrived—Words in Lieu of a Letter**
Cutting iron, severing steel—I do not think of home,
Forever ending doubt, forever abandoning home.
Feet treading white clouds, seeking feathered guests,
Staff bearing the bright moon, visiting immortals’ abodes.
The gardens and halls of home are not my dwelling,
Beyond the world, Penglai is my true home.
At ease and free, without lingering cares,
Why speak again of the old home?

**Again**
Everyone pursues the Dao, all toiling,
Each with lofty hearts, yet none with lofty aspirations.
Smoke and fire unremoved breed resentment and malice,
Worldly passions unsevered give rise to greed and gluttony.
To seek the mysterious and wondrous, dissolve the three karmas,
Fiercely strike at the root with a single blade.
Ever pure, ever clear, ever forbearing,
Non-action, non-striving—join the ranks of immortals.

**Again**
Once shackled by the yoke of profit and fame,
Delighting in the waves of the bitter sea while wearing its chains.
Children and grandchildren at home like jade shackles,
Wives and concubines before the eyes like golden fetters.
How did Ma Yu awaken from such delusion?
Meeting Fengxian, he cast off the yoke.
Seeking leisure within leisure, finding leisure’s delight—
Now, how could I willingly don those chains again?

**Again**
I urge you—do not ask of past causes,
Simply turn back, and it is your destined affinity.
Not pondering the floating life makes sudden awakening hard,
Slightly knowing the peril of emptiness brings you near the good cause.

To enter the Dao without intent requires no distinction,
To seek the Mystery with purpose is to have affinity.
Since ancient times, all immortals have departed the world—
How could one find good causes while dwelling at home?

**Again**
The Wind Immortal’s wind harms to reveal the true wind,
Leaving behind a family tradition to harm the wind.
The adept Qiu Xian of Tongmi succeeded him,
While Shantong and Ma Yu answered the call of Feng.

I urge you—do not dream within a dream,
Learn from me to seek the wind within the wind.
If asked the cause of wind, I plainly declare:
Cast off the worldly, embrace the wind of the heart.

**For Lord Li of Doumen**
No need to seek masters far and wide—
The immortal within is your true master.
Truly pure, truly clear, truly the ultimate principle,
Most subtle, most wondrous, the truest master.

If love and hate remain, the Dao is hard to seek;
With self and others still present, bowing to masters is in vain.
If your will cannot follow mine,
How can my heart be your heart’s master?

**Again**
The wonders of Qin Chuan are truly extraordinary,
Best of all is the treasure-hidden land of Zhongnan.
Bamboo paths and plum streams brim with vital essence,
Phoenix nests and dragon caves exhale auspicious light.

Cloud hermitages gather clouds in every place,
Many Daoist friends discourse on the Dao’s profundity.
The name of Liujiang Village has now changed—
Everyone speaks of the Village of Immortal Meetings.

**Four Poems on the Raft of Immortal Encounter**

**For the Pure Wind Recluse**
Diligently cultivating beyond the world,
Meticulously sweeping the heart within.
Gradually severing worldly ties,
Gently penetrating the Mystery’s depths.

The great elixir forms, numinous and bright,
The divine radiance shines, resplendent.
Fortunately meeting the raft of immortals,
Steadily returning to Penglai Isle.

**Matching the Master’s Rhyme**
The Three Lights firmly anchor the Lower Primordial,
The Six Perfections purify the Middle Realm.
The Nine Cycles’ Upper Primordial lamp
Illumines the moon of eternal life.

Unceasing brightness, day and night,
Radiance flows in an unbroken stream.
Revealing the embryo immortal,
Transcending life and death this time.

**For Master Yan**
Still the heart, cut off right and wrong,
Eradicate intent, remove self and others.
Free from wine, lust, anger, and wealth,
Escape the wheel of life and death.

Auspicious light weaves precious blossoms,
Mysterious dew forms pearl-like drops.
Naturally meeting the raft of immortals,
You may then ride the clouds.

**Again**
With fame achieved, it is good to still the heart,
With profit attained, one may turn back.
Monkey and horse no longer run wild,
Dragon and tiger unite in embrace.

Always keep the jade gate open,
Never let the golden pass leak.
When the Nine Cycles’ great elixir is complete,
Through ten thousand kalpas, the spirit remains clear and refined.

**Twelve Poems on the Hardship of Family Life**

**For Ning Bogong**
Family life is hardship, a pit of fire deep.
Myriad dusts bury one, unbearable to endure.
Meeting the Wind Immortal, seeking beyond the world,
Cultivation is good—refining yin and yang.

Pure and clear, one sees gold in water,
Radiant light shines, veiling the precious peak.

Family life is hardship, constantly busy.
Busy here, busy there, until impermanence arrives.
Becoming a yin prisoner, dwelling in the ghostly abode.

Cultivation is good, never busy,
Leisurely guarding the true constant.
With completion, the jade cavern awaits.

Family life is hardship, providing for others.
Clothed and fed, yet still complaining of poverty.
Scheming with cunning, losing one’s true nature.

Cultivation is good, living as a leisurely person,
Naturally caring for the Dao, not for poverty.
Refining the stubborn heart, nurturing the ultimate truth.

Family life is hardship, like a bee’s devotion.
Gathering flowers to make honey—for whom is it sweet?
If not cautious, caught in the spider’s web.

Cultivation is good, becoming a wind devotee.
The tongue produces jade-like nectar, sweet as ambrosia,
Nourishing the yellow sprout, free from entanglement.

Family life is hardship, especially greedy.
With wealth abundant, still craving high office.
Facing danger, no means of escape.

Cultivation is good, free from greed.
Hiding one’s light, concealing traces, fearing fame.
In non-action, escaping life and death.

Family life is hardship, clinging to worldly ties.
Plotting livelihoods, hoping for a thousand years.
Yet this mortal body is not long enduring.

Cultivation is good, forming good affinities.
With merit complete and conduct fulfilled, no need to count the years.
Becoming an immortal, for the will is steadfast.

Family life is hardship, without end or limit.
One day, the body dies, becoming a yin prisoner.
Facing King Yama, no freedom remains.

Cultivation is good, with a clear path.
With three thousand merits complete, one is no prisoner.
Becoming an immortal, attaining freedom.

Family life is hardship, delighting in opposition.
Constantly pondering the peril of life and death,
Fearing the past, encircled by the fire’s courtyard.

Cultivation is good, abiding in non-action.
The divine pearl’s radiance pierces the curtains,
Revealing the spirit child, majestic in appearance.

Family life is hardship, without respite.
Perilous and dangerous, like a game of encirclement.
Controlled by others, no prayers avail.

Cultivation is good, most rare and wondrous.
The maiden and infant vie to ride tiger and dragon,
Offering the embryo immortal, phoenix and qilin.

Family life is hardship, for wife and children,
Enduring right and wrong, glory and disgrace.
When the limit arrives, how can one bear it?

Cultivation is good, with a son in the south.
The divine elixir shines, abandoning the thatched hut,
Feasting in the Jasper Pool, virtue fully sated.

Cultivation is easy, severing ties is hard.
At first, understanding is most difficult.
Like impermanence, breaking through is arduous.

With the heart awakened, no doubts remain.
Realizing the past hardships of family life,
Learning to be an immortal—what difficulty is there?

Ponder the subtle and wondrous, reflect on worldly ties,
Searching both with precision.
Knowing emptiness, turn firmly to the Dao.

With a pure heart and intent penetrating the Mystery,
Naturally, one understands without words.
Attaining non-action, becoming a great immortal.

**Matching the Ancient Rhyme**
Shantong awoke sharply,

Correcting the root source,

Before others, act small,

Within kan and li, tiger sleeps, dragon rests.

Neither hating nor loving, without self or others,
What worry of misfortune or calamity?
At ease and carefree,
Singing in harmony with cloud companions and rosy friends.

chunks.translated_text:
**Gradual Enlightenment Collection**

**Title:** *Gradual Enlightenment Collection*
**Author:** Jin Mǎyù
**Volumes:** Two
**Source Text:** *Daoist Canon of the Zhengtong Era*, *Taiping* Section

---

**Gradual Enlightenment Collection, Volume I**
*Composed by Mǎ Dānyáng of Mount Kūnyú*

**Congratulating the Sage’s Advent (Two Poems)**
*Presented to Minister Wang*

**I.**
Auspicious mist and blessed *qi* ever spread,
the heart then returns to its primal plain.
The world pursues—yet I abide in non-doing,
thoughtless, careless, free of strain.
Crimson chamber gathers the Maiden and Infant,
their wisdom-eyes watch crow and hare.
The *Kǎn* and *Lí* palaces intertwine—
who among these grasps such affair?

**II.**
Robe of paper, hempen cloth, plain attire,
firmly rooted in the original simplicity.
Before the wind, beneath the moon, I strum the heart’s lute,
untainted by the slightest dust of worry.
Cloud-companions, radiance-friends ever gather,
watching the flying crow, the running hare.
Within the jade, the purple-golden elixir ripens—
who among these grasps such affair?

---

**Picking Mulberries (No. 1)**
*Leaving Home to Enter the Dao*

Fúfēng’s Quán Dào bore the name Tōngyī,
his Daoist title: Carefree.
Beholding a painted skull,
he fiercely gathered his mind—all affairs ceased.
At forty-six, frost silvered his temples,
he brushed his sleeves and wandered the clouds.
No need for stubborn clinging—
it’s like the deadline of impermanence arriving at last.

**II.**
Corpse-walking bones, chasing fame and gain,
fate’s decree is fixed and firm.
They heed not the body’s frame,
skin and skeleton their funeral home.
I urge men to sever the cords of clinging,
leap from the red furnace’s flame.
Restore the primordial state—
there’s a mountain rustic who lends his strength.

**III.**
The mountain rustic cast off the worldly, sought the mysterious,
tying true and good causes.
Deep gratitude to the Perfected Master—
thus he became a carefree, unbound man.

chunks.original_text: 我今誓不东归去，死在西秦。 骸骨虽尘。 不与儿孙葬海滨。 〔梦觉醒悟〕 重阳师父百端诱化，予终有攀绿爱念。 忽一夜，梦立於中庭，自叹曰：我性命有如一只细磁碗，失手百碎。 言未讫，从空碗坠，惊哭觉来。 师翌日乃曰：汝昨晚惊惧，才方省悟。 吕公大悟黄梁梦，舍弃华轩。 返本还源。 出自锺离作大仙。 山侗猛悟细磁梦，割断攀缘。 炼汞烹铅。 出自风仙性月圆。 又 内容未显名先显，事可伤悲。 坏道根基。 失了元初更怨谁。 寻思懵懂胜伶俐，做个愍痴。 无作无为。 缀甚闲词写甚诗。
chunks.translated_text:
I now vow never to return east,
to die in Western Qin.
Though my bones turn to dust,
they’ll not be buried by sons and grandsons by the sea.

**[Dream-Awakening]**
Master Chongyang admonished and guided me in a hundred ways,
yet I remained entangled in attachments.
One night, I dreamed I stood in the central courtyard, sighing:
"My life is like a delicate porcelain bowl—
one slip and it shatters into a hundred pieces."
Before the words were finished, the bowl fell from the sky,
and I awoke with a startled cry.
The next day, the Master said:
"Your terror last night was the first glimmer of awakening."

Lü Dongbin awoke from the Yellow Millet Dream,
abandoned his gilded carriage,
returned to the root, restored the source—
all through Master Zhongli’s alchemy.

The mountain rustic, struck by the porcelain dream,
severed the cords of clinging,
refined mercury, simmered lead—
through the Immortal of the Wind’s nature, the moon became full.

**IV.**
The name appears before the truth is revealed,
a lamentable affair.
It uproots the foundation of the Dao—
who can one blame for losing the primordial state?
Better to be dull and awakened than clever and deluded,
to play the fool,
to act without contrivance,
to cease weaving idle words or composing verses.

chunks.translated_text:
Vows I made—barefoot through summer, never drinking cool water;
through winter, never facing fire’s glow.
Now I swear within these encircling walls:
in summer, I renounce all cooling springs;
in winter, I scorn the reddened embers.
I recognize the true crucible’s water-and-fire affinity.
Longing to repay my Master’s grace, I cultivate with diligence,
refining mercury, simmering lead.
When deeds are complete and merit full,
I shall become a barefoot immortal of Penglai’s isles.

*Tune: "Exploring Spring"*
For Wang Zhixuan

Within the grotto-heaven, several rounds of pure, pure rain—
pointing afar to the jade forest, worth beholding.
A single jade staff, following as I walk,
discovers within my nature the golden lotus blooming.
Youthful maiden and radiant woman come to gather,
joined by the true dragon and tiger.
Naturally, it manifests—
auspicious light covering all,
a single luminous sovereign.

*Cherishing the Fragrant Season: Two Poems*
For Officer Li

You and I, born in the same *gui-mao* year,
unaware that fifty-two years have flowed past.
I entered the Dao first, delving into profound principles,
naturally unwilling to leave you behind.
Day and night without distinction, I constantly attend to it,
scribbling verses and songs on a thousand sheets of paper.
I urge you to early abandon worldly ties,
lest you stumble at the Yellow Springs’ edge.

For Wu Yu, the Desireless, Guardian of Compassion

Pure, pure, and serene—auspicious clouds at their feet.
Within the nine apertures, they interweave and traverse.
Who knows the wondrous function arises from non-action?
Naturally, the principle refines into the elixir.
The black dragon spits forth a divine pearl, resplendent,
revealing ten thousand rays of rosy light enveloping all.
The empty hall gleams, its radiance enhanced—
some promise awaits on Penglai’s path.

*Three Poems to the Tune "Willow Branches"*
For Zhao Daoji

Within the day, the golden rooster crows once,
startling the dream awake.
On the pillow, a lingering coolness from the pure breeze,
the wine just sobered.
Mist rolls back, clouds gather—the sky like water,
the moon newly bright.
The empty hall, silent, utterly free of dust’s passions—
the nature just leveled.

*For the Four Masters of the Countryside*

A *Willow Branches* verse I sweep clean,
to whom shall I send it?
To the one Yan, one Hao, and two Liu Immortals,
I pour forth these words.
Best to join Qiu, Liu, Tan, and Ma,
together to delve into the profound.
When the nine returns and seven reversals complete their work,
go to pay homage at the origin.

For Yunzhongzi, Su Xuan

Fiercely abandoning glory, wife, and children,
awakening to the mystery’s mechanism.
Drifting, drifting—utterly at ease in non-action,
playing the fool.
No wandering through cloud and water on fragrant grass paths—
within, I uphold the practice.
When merit is complete and deeds full,
alone, where shall I go?
I shall hasten to the Jasper Pool.

*Six Poems to the Tune "Fisherman’s Pride"*
Awakening to Myself

chunks.original_text: 梦见娇妻称是母，又逢爱妾还称女。 因为前生心不悟。 心不悟，改头换面为夫妇。 从此山侗常恐惧，那堪更得风仙度。 决要净清清净做。 清浄做，紫芝彼岸通玄路。 又 七十光阴能几日，大都二万五千日。 过了一日无一日。 无一日，看看身似西山日。 不做修行虚度日，悟来岂肯经终日。 斡运洞天真月日。 真月日，蟾宫裹面擎红日。 赠孙姑 奉劝孙姑修大道，时时只把心田扫。 杀了三尸并六耗。 无烦恼，常清常净知玄奥。 休问异名炉与灶，冲和上下通颠倒。 铅汞自然成至宝。 非常好，霞光簇捧归蓬岛。 赠众师兄 奉劝同流听子细，断荤戒酒全容易。 不恋浮财浑小事。 深可畏，轻轻触着无明起。 大抵色心难拚弃，筹来断制须由你。 便把如雠如活鬼。 宜远离，至於梦寐须回避。 又 叮嘱庖人常作善，殷懃供养人休倦。 莫把煎汤倾地面。 摊凉冷，恐伤虫蚁行方便。 日用柴薪并米面，无抛无撒无奢俭。 内外净清忘俗念。 真堪羡，将来次得居仙院。 又 牛驾重车逢恶路，奈人不顾艰难处。 加力用鞭鞭不住。 鞭不住，牛儿忽作人言语。 你为养家予受苦，我今怜汝须词诉。 你若今生心不悟。 心不悟，我身便是将来汝。 柳梢青二首 和古词韵 悟个不生不灭。 更不肯、拈花摘叶。 忻则高歌，醉眠芳草，梦游仙阙。 有时普劝人人，莫讶我、叮咛切切。 走骨行尸，贪财竞色，枉销年月。 又藏头 □轮不催生灭。
chunks.translated_text:
**Dreaming of My Beloved Wife**

I dreamed my tender wife called me "mother,"
and met my cherished concubine—she called me "daughter."
All because in past lives my heart knew no awakening.
*Knew no awakening—*
only to change faces and become husband and wife.

From this, ever trembling in the mountain wilds,
how could I bear further deliverance by Immortal Feng?
I must purify myself and practice purity.
*Practice purity—*
where purple mushrooms mark the far shore, the path to the profound.

**Again**

Seventy years of light—how many days remain?
At most, twenty-five thousand days.
Each day passed leaves one less.
*One less—*
soon this body will be like the sun setting on Western Mountain.

If I do not cultivate the Dao, I waste my days in vain.
Once awakened, how could I idle till my end?
I turn the wheel of the Grotto-Heaven’s true sun and moon.
*True sun and moon—*
in the Moon Palace, I lift the crimson sun.

**To Sister Sun**

I urge you, Sister Sun, to cultivate the Great Dao,
ever sweeping clean the field of your heart.
Slay the Three Corpses and the Six Wastrels.
*Free from affliction—*
ever pure, ever still, you will know the mystery’s depths.

Ask not of strange names for furnace or hearth—
harmony rises and falls, inverting all.
Lead and mercury naturally form the supreme treasure.
*Most excellent—*
clouds of rosy light will escort you to Penglai Isle.

**To My Fellow Practitioners**

I urge you, kindred spirits, to heed me closely:
abstaining from meat and wine is wholly within reach.
Disdaining fleeting wealth is but a trifling matter.
*Yet deeply perilous—*
the slightest touch may rouse the flame of ignorance.

By and large, desire for form is hard to cast aside;
you must resolve to sever it yourself.
Treat it as a foe, as a living ghost.
*Best to keep far away—*
even in dreams, you must shun it.

**Again**

I charge the kitchen master to do good always,
diligently offering sustenance without wearying.
Do not pour boiling broth upon the ground.
*Let it cool—*
lest you harm the ants that pass by.

In daily use of firewood, rice, and flour,
neither waste nor stint—let there be no excess.
Within and without, keep pure, forgetting worldly thoughts.
*Truly admirable—*
in time, you may dwell in the immortals’ courts.

**Again**

An ox pulls a heavy cart on a treacherous road,
yet the driver heeds not the hardship.
He strikes harder with the whip, but the ox will not move.
*Will not move—*
suddenly, the ox speaks in human words:

"You toil to feed your family while I suffer.
Now I must plead with you in pity.
If in this life your heart does not awaken,
*Does not awaken—*
then in the next, *I* shall be *you*."

**Two Poems to the Tune "Green Willow Tips"**

*Matching an Ancient Verse*

Awakened to the unborn and undying,
I refuse to pluck flowers or gather leaves.
Joyful, I sing aloud,
drunk, I sleep on fragrant grass,
dreaming of wandering the immortals’ palaces.

At times, I exhort all people—
do not wonder at my earnest, repeated pleas.
Walking corpses, bone-bags,
greedy for wealth, racing after desire,
they squander their years in vain.

**Again**

*Hidden Head*

□ The wheel does not hasten birth or death.

□ within the flame, lotus blooms with five petals.
□ attains the golden flower, □ forms the magic herb,
□ divides without lack.
□ born Ma Yu, a foolish man,
□ suddenly awakened—his family ties cut deep.
□ split the mountain of grace, □ illumined for ages,
□ discoursed on the moon of the heart.

**Two Poems to the Tune "Welcoming Spring Joy"**

*For Master Ru*

Within the body, timely signs ascend in purity and elegance—
why need the pitch-pipes or clay oxen?
The herb-field relies on clouds to plow through,
no longer requiring the plowman’s hand.
Cultivating life and spreading virtue, the work is complete,
golden sprouts bloom everywhere, surpassing flowers and willows.
The Jade Grotto bears the immortal embryo—
naturally, one drinks the wine of longevity.

*For Master Liu*

The Dipper’s handle turns, first arriving at *Zhen*,
naturally, yang qi surges and swells.
How can the blue bird’s tidings be endured?
The earth-ox strikes—know the season’s division.
The sun travels the western path, golden light gleaming,
golden sprouts and auspicious herbs, magic fungi moistened.
Delighting in the nine-returned elixir,
opening the jade feast—all should be in perfect order.

**To the Tune "Jade Tower Spring"**

*For Jiang Daoquan*

The master drinks the jade nectar’s wine,
reclines beneath the moon, sleeps among clouds, idly toying with the Dipper.
Timely, he revolves the mechanism without error—
this work depends on the craftsman’s hand.
A hall filled with gold and jade, existing within nothingness,
the nation prosperous, the people at peace, spirit and qi refined.
The jade tower’s spring colors are wondrous indeed—
not the orioles, flowers, or green willows.

**To the Tune "Palace of Night Travel"**

Seeing through worldly toil, bitter and relentless,
delighting in purity and leisure, freely singing and dancing.
Like a solitary cloud, coming and going.
No entanglements—attaining carefree ease,
within, self-replenished.
Day and night, harmonizing dragon and tiger,
constantly, the maiden and infant gather.
Cultivating the divine pearl, it emits light from emptiness.
Radiating brilliance—
revealing the original beginning,
the master of form.

**To the Tune "Jade Hall Spring"**

Idly discussing cultivation—
cultivation is no trifling matter.
Fiercely abandoning family ties,
only then seeking the Great Dao.
Extinguishing all ignorance,
like *Ke*, nurturing the vast.
Willing to follow human sentiments like a well-sweep?
Dwelling in a wren’s nest, eating scraps—
naturally free from vexation.
A grimy face, disheveled hair,
the field of the heart frequently swept.
Metal and wood mutually engender—
within, the supreme treasure is formed.
Then, the divine light emits a single ray.
Treading the clouds, walking...

**Thirty Poems to the Tune "Treading Clouds" #2**

*For Immortals Cao, Gan, and Zhang, Dwelling Together in Misty Rosy Grotto*

Two counties, three immortals,
one heart, dwelling together,
passing down the profoundest words in turn.
By the water-cloud stream, joyfully carefree,
within Misty Rosy Grotto, thoughts forgotten.
Refining mercury, cooking lead,
harmonizing dragon, guiding tiger,
in stillness, uniting the true lords of the three fields.
The work complete, riding a crane to pay homage to the Origin—
in the Great Luo Heaven, becoming immortal companions.

chunks.original_text: 又 自在闲人，逍遥烈士，清贫快乐忘尘事。 风前月下抚心琴，龙昤虎啸来参侍。 或隐山林，或居尘市，劝人回首头头是。 尘中诱化结良缘，云朋霞友应翘俟。 赠吕守真 此个姑姑，谪仙姓吕，肯来贩骨为商旅。 蓬头垢面道家风，云朋霞友非凡侣。 莫骋容仪，一团臭腐，恩情劈碎非斤斧。 心灰念断乐逍逼，大罗天上居仙府。 又 六出飘扬，万峰潜翠，琼花陨地风吹起。 穿帘透幕逞逍遥，人前故要呈祥瑞。 渔父莎披，子猷兴至，高阳酒价重增贵。 万民何事有余欢，来年定是成丰岁。 赠冯守慈 男女虽亲，死生难越，浮名浮利浮云朵。 万缘一撇恰如无，长生路上修仙果。 玉户频开，金关紧锁，灵珠裹面持经课。 功成轻举踏云行，大罗天上端严坐。 又 重遇重阳，重重悟道，扶风马子何愁老。 调龙引虎弄明珠，明珠出路应须早。 以钰为名，字呼玄宝，云中子得为佳号。 木牛小字字山侗，山侗指日登仙好。 又 重到兴平，广开言路，蓦然兴尽思归去。 踏莎行计指长安，愿人早早心开悟。 贫富由天，子孙阴注，算来分定休思虑。 闻身康健速修持，真诚博个真师度。 赠无为散人 三髻山侗，拜闻张氏，看人布施终非是。 临渊休羡锦鳞肥，退而结网胜瞻视。 欲住蓬瀛，何劳翘俟，蓬头垢面忘尘事。 焚香百拜本夫心，同修愿继庞居士。 赠丫髻姚玄玉 丫髻之中，明藏两吉，师名顶戴休更易。 锺离昔日亦如斯，姚公仿效宁无益。 性烛修完，命灯挑剔，灵光朗照知无极。 迎仙客唱踏云行，瑶台月裹投端的。 〔和师韵〕 师父赠谭仙词曰：张公吃酒李公来，李公夺了张公饮。 击发钰谨和。 豁豁洋洋，详详审审，仙家出语何须恁。
chunks.translated_text:
**Further Verses to the Tune "Treading Clouds"**

Another:
A carefree idler, a careless hero,
in poverty and joy, worldly matters forgotten.
Before the wind, beneath the moon, plucking the heart’s zither,
dragon’s chants and tiger’s roars come to attend.
Now hidden in mountain forests, now dwelling in bustling markets,
urging others to turn their heads—each step is the Way.
Amid the dust, guiding and transforming, forging good karmic ties;
cloud companions and rosy friends await in anticipation.

*For Lü Shouzhen*
This maiden,
a banished immortal surnamed Lü,
willing to trade bones as a merchant.
Disheveled hair, grimy face—Daoist bearing,
cloud companions and rosy friends, no ordinary fellowship.
Do not flaunt your appearance,
a lump of foul decay—
affection shattered not by axe or adze.
Heart extinguished, thoughts severed, joy unbounded,
in the Great Luo Heaven, dwelling in the immortal palace.

Another:
Six-petaled flurries drift,
a thousand peaks lie in hidden emerald,
jade blossoms fallen to earth, stirred by the wind.
Through curtains and screens, flaunting their freedom,
before men, deliberately displaying auspicious signs.
The fisherman dons his straw cloak,
Ziyou’s mood arises,
the price of wine in Gaoyang soars.
Why do the people rejoice so?—
next year will surely be a year of abundance.

*For Feng Shouci*
Though kin by blood,
life and death cannot be crossed.
Fleeting fame, fleeting gain—like drifting clouds.
All ties cast aside, as if nonexistent,
on the path of longevity, cultivating the immortal fruit.
Jade doors often opened,
golden gates tightly sealed,
the spirit pearl veiled, scriptures recited.
Work complete, lightly ascending, treading the clouds,
in the Great Luo Heaven, seated in solemn dignity.

Another:
Reencountering Chongyang,
layer upon layer, awakening to the Dao,
the lad from Fufeng—why fear aging?
Harmonizing dragon, guiding tiger, toying with the bright pearl,
the bright pearl’s path must emerge early.
Named *Yu*, styled *Xuanbao*,
the title *Cloud Master* earned as a fine sobriquet.
The Wooden Ox’s childhood name: *Shantong*,
*Shantong* will soon ascend as an immortal.

Another:
Returning to Xingping,
broadening the path of words,
suddenly, interest spent, thoughts turn to home.
Treading the mossy path, counting the way to Chang’an,
wishing all would awaken their hearts early.
Wealth and poverty decreed by heaven,
descendants’ fortunes inscribed in shadow,
calculations set—cease all worry.
Hearing the body is sound, hasten to cultivate;
with sincerity, seek a true master’s guidance.

*For the Idle Daoist of Wuwei*
The three-topknot *Shantong*, bowing to hear Zhang’s teaching,
watching others make offerings—this is not the way.
Do not envy the fat carp by the river’s edge;
retreat and cast your net—better than gazing.
To dwell in Penglai,
why wait in anticipation?
Disheveled hair, grimy face, worldly matters forgotten.
Burning incense, bowing a hundred times to the original heart,
vowing to follow in the footsteps of Master Pang.

*For Yaji Yao Xuanyu*
Within the twin topknots,
brightness and fortune concealed,
the master’s name worn on the crown—do not alter it.
Long ago, Zhongli was just the same;
can Yao’s emulation lack benefit?
The candle of nature refined to perfection,
the lamp of life trimmed and bright,
the spirit’s light shining boundlessly.
The *Immortal-Welcoming Guest* sings *Treading Clouds*,
in the moonlit jade terrace, striking the mark.

*Matching the Master’s Rhyme*
The master’s verse for Immortal Tan:
*Zhang drinks wine, Li arrives,*
*Li seizes Zhang’s cup and drinks.*
Struck by inspiration, Yu humbly responds:
Vast and free,
detailed and precise,
why must the immortals’ words be so?

ao, Gan, and Zhang, Dwelling Together in Misty Rosy Grotto*

Two counties, three immortals,
one heart, dwelling together,
passing down the profoundest words in turn.
By the water-cloud stream, joyfully carefree,
within Misty Rosy Grotto, thoughts forgotten.
Refining mercury, cooking lead,
harmonizing dragon, guiding tiger,
in stillness, uniting the true lords of the three fields.
The work complete, riding a crane to pay homage to the Origin—
in the Great Luo Heaven, becoming immortal companions.

chunks.original_text: 山侗自揣一鳌鱼，金鳞晃日如新锦。 云水逍遥，身心恣任，欲为上士相争甚。 大家共喜白衣来，玄中玄酒宜同饮。 师父引马钰上街求乞 不说龟毛，无论兔角，幻躯闲想如蝉壳。 怎生亦得显金容，算来全在心知觉。 志不回环，道非遥邈，洞天白雪成红雹。 化为自在个灵童，自然掌握长生药。 茶 绝品堪称，奇名甚当，消磨睡思功无量。 仲尼不复梦周公，山侗大笑陈搏强。 七椀卢全，赵州和尚，曾知滋味归无上。 宰予若得一杯尝，永无昼寝神清爽。 道士索 东布烟萝，西排雪柳，秦川渭水添清秀。 四方八表涌金莲，祥光瑞气轻轻覆。 九转经营，一时功就，自然玉殿成无漏。 三清高坐宝花台，谁知此景无中有。 赴刘公斋 玉液琼浆，调和玉屑，便教玉案堆冰雪。 须凭玉杖作良工，捍成玉饼轻轻迭。 蓦听金声，金刀细切，金炉裹面烹无歇。 馨香软美喂金牛，金牛饱后无生灭。 葡萄 根蒂蟠虬，龙须围绕，枝枝叶叶青青好。 三光照曜结云棚，就中几穗非常宝。 初似瑠璃，终成码碯，攒攒簇簇圆圆小。 数珠相似恐人偷，马风吃了归蓬岛。 又 三髻轩昂，一般仙格，宜乎花戴青黄白。 这些道意少人知，马风再遇亲传得。 欲要修持，须依法则，日来月往通关脉。 烹铅炼汞结金丹，功成行满蓬瀛客。 全真堂竹帘 白刃持，青丝作线，一经一纬挨排遍。 功成不敢挂茅檐，全真堂裹垂方便。 隔断尘嚣，内容自见，闲闲不用他人卷。 月钩高钓入青霄，恁时争看扶风面。 又 马钰平生，心平性善，因师钓出牟平县。 逍遥坦荡过东平，平安无事身康健。 得到兴平，治平为念，清平快乐无征战。 云游地脉太平宫，平平稳稳行方便。 又 偶尔心明，自然灵感，宝珠出入骊龙颔。 真常常应显昭彰，性通通达无昏暗。 处世悭贪，则吾岂敢，缊袍共敝而无憾。 争名竞利我输君，眠云卧月君输。 真武宫道士索 真武藏机，真君弃假，荣华富贵须当舍。 手持慧剑杀三尸，龟蛇一气相迎迓。 灵应通明，神清幽雅，知白守黑些儿话。 愿人省悟踏云行，好来相伴扶风马。 谢李师叔鞋 高上先生，先生姓李，怜予乡远三千里。 教言滋味胜琼浆，寻思不让元王醴。 见赠予鞋，鞋非鞋履，藏机隐密传玄理。 从今无分踏红尘，有缘走上青霄裹。 赠骆进道先为铁匠 跳出红炉，身无烧烙，水云游历非流落。 晨昏调弄自然琴，清清滋味胜酥酪。 逗引灵童，常交欢乐，八渠流水成璎珞。 兀谁占得此家风，知新进道长安乐。 赠张公 不惑之年，心宜不动，常思玉杻金柳重。 无常一着可伤悲，悟时速把良缘种。 鄙了惺惺，庄成懵懂，修完内貌频看供。 功成行满去朝元，瑞云衬步香风送。 〔还乡〕 先祖兄弟四人，因唐末去山东，一居莱阳，一住黄县，一在文登，一居牟平。 祖住云阳，嵯峨山下，自来生计之乎者。 却因唐末去东牟，到今三百余年也。 数世衰荣，不堪重话，我今因遇家缘舍。 水云游历入潼关，超然显个还乡马。 仵寿之生日设醮索词 谨写青词，专修黄箓，香茶酒果并香烛。 钟声磬韵透青霄，科仪款款当宣读。 瑞气氤氲，祥烟馥郁，金童玉女传言速。 不惟寿永过松筠，仁人可以同仙福。 又 遍室清凉，满堂功德，四方八表无遮塞。 灵光万道出昆仑，人前岂敢夸仙格。
chunks.translated_text:
The Mountain Recluse sees himself as a giant turtle-fish,
golden scales gleaming like fresh brocade in the sun.
Roaming clouds and waters at will,
body and mind freely given,
why vie to be the foremost adept?
All rejoice at the coming of the white-robed one—
in the mystery within mystery, wine should be shared.

*Master Leads Ma Yu to Beg in the Streets*
No need to speak of turtle-hair,
no need to discuss rabbit-horns—
the illusory body’s idle thoughts are but a cicada’s husk.
How then might one reveal the golden countenance?
All lies in the heart’s awareness.
Unwavering resolve,
the Dao not distant,
the cave-heaven’s white snow turns to crimson hail.
Transformed into a carefree spirit-child,
naturally grasping the elixir of immortality.

*Tea*
A peerless grade, its name most fitting,
dispelling sleep’s thoughts with boundless merit.
Confucius no longer dreams of the Duke of Zhou—
the Mountain Recluse laughs heartily at Chen Tuan’s boast.
Lu Tong’s seven bowls,
Master Zhaozhou—
both knew its supreme savor.
Had Zai Yu tasted but one cup,
he’d never nap by day, his spirit clear and bright.

*The Daoist Requests*
Eastern cloth of misty creepers,
western rows of snow willows,
the Qin River and Wei waters add fresh beauty.
In all directions golden lotuses surge,
auspicious light and propitious qi gently descend.
Nine cycles of refinement,
instant completion—
naturally the Jade Palace stands leak-proof.
The Three Pure Ones sit high on jeweled flower thrones—
who knows this scene arises from nothingness?

*Attending Lord Liu’s Feast*
Jade nectar and fine wine,
blended with jade shards,
piling the jade table with ice and snow.
Rely on the jade staff as skilled craftsman,
kneading jade cakes, lightly layered.
Suddenly hearing golden chimes,
golden blades slice finely,
golden stoves ceaselessly simmer.
Fragrant and soft, feeding the golden ox—
once sated, the golden ox knows no birth or death.

*Grapes*
Roots coiled like dragons,
tendrils twining,
branch by branch, leaf by leaf, lush and green.
The Three Luminaries shine upon the cloud-canopied vines,
among them, several clusters of extraordinary treasure.
At first like lapis lazuli,
finally like agate,
clustered and dense, round and small.
Like prayer beads, lest thieves steal—
Ma Feng ate them and returned to Penglai Isle.

*Again*
Three topknots towering,
a singular immortal’s bearing,
fitting to wear flowers of blue, yellow, and white.
This Daoist intent few understand—
Ma Feng once more receives the direct transmission.
To cultivate and uphold,
follow the method and rule,
days and months passing through the meridians.
Refining lead and mercury to form the golden elixir,
completing merit and fulfilling the journey as a Penglai guest.

*Bamboo Blind for the Quanzhen Hall*
White blades held taut,
blue silk as thread,
warp and weft meticulously aligned.
The work complete, dare not hang it beneath the thatched eaves—
in the Quanzhen Hall, it hangs for convenience.
Shielding from worldly clamor,
inner truth self-evident,
leisurely, no need for others to roll it up.
The moon’s hook high, angling into azure skies—
then all will vie to see the visage of Fufeng.

*Again*
Ma Yu’s lifelong nature,
heart level and disposition kind,
drawn out by his master from Muping County.
Roaming carefree and unburdened through Dongping,
safe and sound, body hale and hearty.
Reaching Xingping,
governing with peace in mind,
joyful and serene, free from strife.
Cloud-wandering the earth veins of the Taiping Palace,
steadily and surely practicing convenience.

*Again*
Occasionally the heart brightens,
naturally the spirit responds—
a pearl emerges from the black dragon’s jaws.
True constancy ever manifest and clear,
nature unimpeded, no darkness.
In worldly dealings, frugal and ungreedy—
how dare I claim such?
Wrapped in a worn robe, content.
Vying for fame and profit, you surpass me;
sleeping among clouds and moon, I surpass you.

*The Daoist of the Zhenwu Temple Requests*
Zhenwu conceals his mechanism,
the Perfected Lord discards the false—
glory, wealth, and honor must be relinquished.
Wielding the sword of wisdom to slay the Three Corpses,
tortoise and snake unite in welcome.
Spirit responsive and luminous,
divine clarity and refined elegance—
knowing white, guarding black, a few words suffice.
May all awaken and tread the cloud path,
happily accompanying Fufeng’s Ma.

*Thanking Master Uncle Li for the Shoes*
Exalted Master,
Master surnamed Li,
pitying my distant homeland, three thousand leagues away.
Your teachings’ savor surpasses jade nectar—
reflecting, not inferior to King Yuan’s sweet wine.
Bestowing me with shoes,
shoes yet not mere footwear—
concealing mechanism, transmitting profound principle.
Henceforth, no parting from the red dust,
with karmic affinity, ascending into azure skies.

*To Luo Jindao, Formerly a Blacksmith*
Leaping from the red furnace,
body free from burns,
roaming water and clouds, not adrift.
Morning and evening tuning the natural zither,
its pure savor surpassing butter and cheese.
Beckoning the spirit-child,
ever joyful in communion—
eight streams of flowing water form garlands.
Who now occupies this family’s way?
Know that newly entering the Dao brings lasting bliss.

*To Lord Zhang*
At the age of unconfusion,
the heart should remain unmoved,
ever mindful of jade handcuffs and golden willows’ weight.
A single misstep of impermanence brings sorrow—
awakening, swiftly plant good causes.
Abandoning vigilance,
becoming dull and muddled—
refine the inner visage, frequently inspecting offerings.
Completing merit and fulfilling the journey, depart to pay homage to the Origin—
auspicious clouds cushion your steps, fragrant winds escort you.

*Returning Home*
Ancestors, four brothers,
at the end of the Tang, left for Shandong—
one settled in Laiyang, one in Huang County,
one in Wendeng, one in Muping.
Ancestors dwelled in Yunyang,
beneath Cuo’e Mountain,
living by the rhythms of *zhi* and *hu* since time immemorial.
Yet at the Tang’s end, they left for Dongmu—
to this day, over three hundred years have passed.
Generations of decline and prosperity,
too much to recount—
now, encountering the relinquishing of family ties.
Roaming water and clouds, entering Tong Pass,
transcendently revealing the returning-home Ma.

*For Wu Shouzhi’s Birthday Feast*
Respectfully writing the blue prayer,
solemnly performing the yellow register rites,
with fragrant tea, wine, fruit, and candles.
Bell tones and chime rhythms pierce azure skies—
the liturgy’s details duly proclaimed.
Auspicious qi swirling,
propitious smoke fragrant and dense—
golden lads and jade maidens swiftly convey the words.
Not only longevity surpassing pines and bamboos,
the benevolent may share in immortal blessings.

*Again*
The chamber cool throughout,
the hall filled with merit—
in all directions, no obstructions.
A myriad rays of spiritual light issue from Kunlun—
how dare I boast of immortal stature before others?

chunks.original_text: 缄口无言，灰心有则，姓名已录华胥国。 逍遥自在看长安，金花玉药亲收得。 谢于公鞋 走入玄门，牵回白鲤，缀词感谢吾侪履。 从今步步出红尘，无心着去观桃李。 采访幽微，搜寻至理，因师大悟离乡里。 一朝功满踏云行，邀公同去青霄裹。 又 耳听金经，口餐玉饼，手持象管书心印。 虽然事事竞相萦，真如不动常清净。 欲要灵明，须磨内镜，居尘不染真常应。 真常应后显胎仙，胎仙显后真常定。 又 捉住飞乌，牢擒走兔，二轮日月常相聚。 光明照耀洞中天，清清雨降如甘露。 拨散浮云，宁留薄雾，蓬莱仙子时时遇。 从斯道号号丹阳，将来决定朝元去。 赠薛公藏头 □敢轻传，□专秘诀，□谈岂比寻常说。 □田震地坎离攒，□珠颗颗须调摄。 □子佳人，□然离别，□圭欲炼朝金阙。 □生马钰踏云行，□咛嘱汝心猿歇。 卜算子八首 人识山侗字，谁晓山侗意。 大貌山侗人倚山，故作山侗谜。 豺色山侗弃，玄妙山侗秘。 一日山侗乐道成，永占山侗位。 又 燕至清明近，花到清明盛。 奉劝清明游赏人，别有清明景。 我得清明永，旷劫清明净。 一点清明无价珍，便是清明性。 又 我为中秋说，休赏中秋节。 外景中秋不益人，内景中秋别。 心到中秋歇，尘自中秋绝。 金遇中秋结大丹，性似中秋月。 又 洒扫阳关路，开阐阳关户。
chunks.translated_text:
Silent, wordless,
heart reduced to ashes—yet with principle:
my name already inscribed in Hua Xu’s land.
Carefree and at ease, gazing upon Chang’an,
golden blossoms and jade elixirs personally gathered.

*In Gratitude for Master Yu’s Shoes*
Stepping into the Mystery Gate,
leading back the white carp,
composing verses to thank our companion’s tread.
From now on, step by step beyond the red dust,
with no heart to linger gazing at peach and plum.

Seeking the subtle,
searching for the ultimate truth,
through the master’s guidance, awakening to leave home.
One day, merits complete, treading clouds in ascent,
inviting you to join within the azure skies.

*Again*
Ears attuned to golden scriptures,
mouth savoring jade cakes,
hand holding the ivory brush to inscribe the heart’s seal.
Though myriad affairs vie for attention,
true suchness remains unmoved, ever pure.

To attain spiritual clarity,
one must polish the inner mirror,
abiding in the world yet unstained—truly responsive.
When truly responsive, the embryonic immortal appears;
when the embryonic immortal appears, true constancy is settled.

*Again*
Seizing the soaring crow,
firmly capturing the fleeing hare—
the two wheels of sun and moon ever conjoined.
Radiance illumines the cavern-heaven,
pure rain descends like sweet dew.
Dispelling floating clouds,
leaving only wispy mist,
immortals of Penglai often encountered.
Henceforth, the Daoist name is Dan Yang;
in time, surely ascending to the Origin.

*For Master Xue (Hidden Head Poem)*
□ dare lightly transmit,
□ guard the secret formula,
□ discourse—how could it compare to ordinary speech?
□ fields quake with Kan and Li’s gathering,
□ pearls, each one requiring regulation.
□ gentleman and fair lady,
□ suddenly parting,
□ jade tablet to refine at the Golden Gate.
□ Ma Yu, born, treading clouds in ascent,
□ earnestly admonishing you: still the mind-monkey.

*Eight Lyrics to the Tune "Divining the Scholar"*
People know Mountain Recluse’s name,
but who fathoms Mountain Recluse’s intent?
The great form of Mountain Recluse leans on mountains,
thus crafting Mountain Recluse’s riddles.
The leopard’s mien, Mountain Recluse abandons;
the profound mystery, Mountain Recluse conceals.
One day, Mountain Recluse’s joy in the Dao complete,
eternally occupying Mountain Recluse’s place.

*Again*
Swallows arrive as Clear Bright nears,
flowers bloom at Clear Bright’s height.
I urge those who roam on Clear Bright’s day:
another Clear Bright’s scene awaits.
I attain Clear Bright’s eternity,
through kalpas, Clear Bright’s purity.
A single point of Clear Bright—priceless treasure—
is Clear Bright’s very nature.

*Again*
I speak for Mid-Autumn,
do not celebrate Mid-Autumn’s festival.
The outer scene of Mid-Autumn brings no benefit;
the inner scene of Mid-Autumn differs.
When the heart reaches Mid-Autumn’s rest,
the dust is severed at Mid-Autumn.
Gold meets Mid-Autumn to congeal the Great Elixir—
nature like the Mid-Autumn moon.

*Again*
Sweeping the Yang Pass road,
opening wide the Yang Pass door.

chunks.original_text: 此个阳关无点尘，堪饯阳关侣。 既得阳关趣，怎肯阳关住。 放出阳关成道人，起自阳关悟。 又 师父重阳号，炼就重阳宝。 紫诏重阳赴玉京，方显重阳好。 我为重阳到，庵为重阳造。 特为重阳守服居，符合重阳道。 又 我遇重阳悟，曾得重阳趣。 炼就重阳绝尽阴，阴就重阳着。 性命重阳聚，三曜重阳辅。 不到重阳不做仙，仙自重阳做。 和师韵 业重多思算，岂悟爻和彖。 深谢风仙特地来，便把顽愚唤。 忿怒常思难，性烛须教灿。 真乐真欢散尽愁，师弟常为伴。 带暍马－声 终日驾盐车，鞭棒时时打。 自叹精神久屈沉，如病马，怎得常游冶。 伯乐相师来，见从频嗟讶。 巧计多方赎了身，得志马，须报师恩也。 又 天地水三官，下界吹龙笛。 蓦听开元虎啸声，风伯雨师寂。 至孝养孀亲，红锦蛇吞鼊。 六路青牛驾宝车，显圣功端的。 又 干禄已无心，唯应三清举。
chunks.translated_text:
This Yang Pass bears not a speck of dust,
fit to bid farewell to Yang Pass companions.
Having grasped Yang Pass’s delight,
how could one dwell in Yang Pass?
Releasing Yang Pass’s perfected Daoist,
awakening arises from Yang Pass’s insight.

*Again*
Master’s name is Chongyang,
having refined Chongyang’s treasure.
The purple decree summons Chongyang to Jade Capital—
only then does Chongyang’s excellence appear.
I arrive for Chongyang’s sake,
the hut built for Chongyang’s dwelling.
Especially to keep vigil for Chongyang’s observance,
in accord with Chongyang’s Way.

*Again*
I met Chongyang and awakened,
once tasted Chongyang’s delight.
Refining Chongyang to extinguish all yin,
yin adheres to Chongyang’s touch.
Life and nature gather in Chongyang,
the Three Luminaries aid Chongyang.
Without reaching Chongyang, one cannot become immortal—
immortality is made by Chongyang alone.

*Matching the Master’s Rhyme*
Karma heavy with many calculations,
how could one awaken to hexagrams and judgments?
Deep gratitude to Wind Immortal for coming especially,
rousing this dull and foolish one.
Anger and resentment often bring hardship,
the lamp of nature must be made to shine.
True joy, true delight scatter all sorrow—
master and disciple ever companions.

*Song of the Overheated Horse*
All day pulling the salt cart,
whips and rods striking ceaselessly.
I sigh—my spirit long suppressed,
like a sick horse, how can I ever roam freely?
Bo Le, the master physiognomist, arrives,
seeing me, he sighs in surprise again and again.
With clever plans and many ways, he ransoms my body—
the horse that has found its will
must repay the master’s kindness.

*Again*
The Three Officials of Heaven, Earth, and Water,
below the realm, blow the dragon flute.
Suddenly hearing the roar of the Kaiyuan tiger,
Wind Earl and Rain Master fall silent.
Utmost filial piety supports a widowed mother,
the red brocade snake swallows the soft-shelled turtle.
The Six-Road Green Ox pulls the treasure carriage—
manifesting sacred merit in truth.

*Again*
I have no heart for seeking office,
only responding to the Three Pures’ summons.

chunks.original_text: 锺吕天差作试官，取舍非诗赋。 考校实修持，功行三千数。 相应希夷得自然，名录神仙簿。 恣逍遥（殢人娇） 赠韩守玄 恣意逍遥，逍遥恣意。 逍遥自在无萦击。 行坐逍遥，逍遥似醉。 逍逼到处，似云似水。 悟彻逍遥，逍遥养气。 逍遥裹面修仙计。 这个逍遥，逍遥无比。 逍遥去、蓬岛十洲有位。 长思仙（长相思》二＋三首 茶 一枪茶，二旗茶。 休献机心名利家。 无眠为作差。 无为茶，自然茶。 天赐休心与道家。 无眠功行加。 又 紫芝汤，紫芝汤。 一遍煎时一遍香。 一杯万事忘。 神砂汤，神砂汤。 服罢主宾分两厢。 携云现玉皇。 与刘处玄并示孟四元 看阳刘，看阳刘。 福杖心持占岸头。 眠云枕逆流。 万缘休，万缘休。 金木相生性转柔。 丹成赴十洲。 又
chunks.translated_text:
Zhong and Lü, Heaven’s appointed examiners,
judge not by poetry or rhapsody.
They weigh true cultivation and discipline—
three thousand deeds of merit and conduct.
Those who align with the Profound and Invisible attain spontaneity,
their names inscribed in the Register of Divine Immortals.
Then freely roam—*(Tiren Jiao)*

*To Han Shouxuan*
Freely roam, roam freely at will.
Roaming freely, untrammeled, without care.
Moving or sitting, roam freely,
freely roaming as if drunk.
Roaming wherever one pleases,
like clouds, like water.
Awakened to free roaming,
freely roaming to nurture qi.
Within free roaming, devise the plan for immortal cultivation.
This free roaming,
unmatched in its freedom.
Freely roam away—to Peng Isle and the Ten Continents, find your place.

*Longing for the Immortal (Chang Xiangsi)* Two + Three Poems

*Tea*
First flush tea, second leaf tea.
Do not offer to the scheming, fame-and-profit household.
Sleeplessness makes it a burden.

Wuwei tea, natural tea.
Heaven bestows it to ease the mind of Daoist households.
Sleeplessness enhances merit and conduct.

*Again*
Purple Ganoderma decoction, purple Ganoderma decoction.
With each brewing, fragrance arises anew.
One cup—all affairs forgotten.

Divine Cinnabar decoction, divine Cinnabar decoction.
After drinking, host and guest part ways.
Carrying clouds, the Jade Emperor appears.

*To Liu Chuxuan, Also Presented to Meng Siyuan*
Observe Yang Liu, observe Yang Liu.
With a fortune staff, heart steadfast, he occupies the riverbank.
Sleeping on clouds, pillowing against the current.

Ten thousand entanglements cease, ten thousand entanglements cease.
Metal and wood mutually engender, nature turns gentle.
The elixir perfected, he departs for the Ten Continents.

chunks.original_text: 梦轩辕，弃田园。 难继夷门孟四元。 惟修性月圆。 缚心猿，认根源。 小小蛇儿俯视鼋。 阳纯礼太原。 又 遇重阳，牧青羊。 不着虚名远远扬。 惟修性日旸。 慕荀杨，乐飘扬。 豁豁洋洋豁豁洋。 通玄风害佯。 往南京搬取风仙灵衬 马风乾，有微言。 一别风仙恰二年。 思心似倒悬。 去无缘，阙盘缠。 乞化长安自肯钱。 成人在众贤。 又 马山侗，马山侗。 与个丘仙和不同。 心交有始终。 合西东，合西东。 慧目相看别有功。 时时现内容。 正家丰，不争锋。 猛烈灰心王害风。 先归三岛峰。 马山侗，过临潼。 三髻头梳似小童。 专专化个同。 又
chunks.translated_text:
Dream of the Yellow Emperor, abandon fields and gardens.
Hard to follow Yi Gate’s Meng Siyuan.
Only cultivate the full moon of inner nature.

Tame the monkey-mind, recognize the root source.
A small serpent gazes down upon the turtle.
Yang Chunli of Taiyuan.

*Again*
Encounter Chongyang, herd the green sheep.
Shun empty fame, let it spread far and wide.
Only cultivate the sunlit nature.

Admire Xun and Yang, delight in the drifting.
Vast and boundless, vast and boundless.
The wind of *Tongxuan* feigns harm.

To Nanjing, to fetch Fengxian’s sacred garments—
Ma Fenggan, with subtle words.
Parted from Fengxian just two years,
Longing weighs like inverted suspension.

Gone without affinity, lacking travel funds.
Begging alms in Chang’an, self-reliant in coin.
Success rests with the assembly of worthies.

*Again*
Ma Shantong, Ma Shantong.
Unlike the Qiu Immortal’s harmony.
Heart’s bond has beginning and end.

Unite East and West, unite East and West.
Wise eyes perceive another merit.
Ever revealing inner content.

Rectify the household’s abundance, not contending for supremacy.
Fierce resolve turns to ashes—Wang Hai’s wind.
First return to the Three Isles’ peaks.

Ma Shantong, passing through Lintong.
Three topknots combed like a youth.
Dedicated to converting the like-minded.

*Again*

chunks.original_text: 入南京，赴蓬瀛。 显出王风九转成。 超然得上升。 宠何荣，辱何惊。 三髻山恫绝利名。 何愁性不灵。 赠小张仙 小张仙，小张仙。 款款搜寻汞与铅。 先须缚马猿。 气绵绵，气绵绵。 龙虎相交玉蕊鲜。 金丹一粒圆。 赠任仙 左擎苍，右牵黄。 昔日存心飞走忙。 如今万事忘。 饮琼浆，宴明堂。 瑞气祥光入绛房。 无中得弄璋。 又 爇银釭，虎龙降。 自在逍遥吸九江。 从思恶肉腔。 结红霜，赴蓬庄。 万朵金莲簇宝幢。 方知好道庞。 寄长春子丘通密 长思仙，长思仙。 思忆长春子最贤。 何时得面圆。 展花笺，展花笺。 写就清吟三两篇。 专凭鸾鹤传。 又 功要圆，行要圆。
chunks.translated_text:
To Nanjing, to the Peng-Ying Isles,
Revealing Wang Feng’s ninefold perfection.
Transcendent, ascending on high.

What glory honors, what disgrace alarms?
The Three-Knot Mountain pities those bound to fame and gain.
Why fear the spirit’s dullness?

*For Little Zhang the Immortal*

Little Zhang the Immortal, Little Zhang the Immortal,
Gently seeking mercury and lead.
First must bind the horse and ape.

Qi unbroken, qi unbroken,
Dragon and tiger intertwine, jade pistil fresh.
A single golden elixir, round.

*For Ren the Immortal*

Left hand holding green, right leading yellow,
Once the heart stored flight and haste.
Now all things forgotten.

Drinking jade nectar, feasting in the Hall of Light,
Auspicious qi and propitious radiance enter the crimson chamber.
From nothingness, a jade scepter gained.

*Again*

Igniting the silver lamp, tiger and dragon descend,
At ease and carefree, absorbing the nine rivers.
Abandoning the foul fleshly frame.

Binding the red frost, hastening to Peng’s estate,
Ten thousand golden lotuses cluster ‘round the jeweled banner.
Only then is Peng’s fine Dao known.

*For Qiu the Perfected of Everlasting Spring*

Ever longing for the immortal, ever longing for the immortal,
Recalling Qiu the Perfected, most worthy.
When shall we meet in fullness?

Unfolding the flowered stationery, unfolding the flowered stationery,
Inscribing a few verses of pure chant.
Entrusted solely to the phoenix and crane.

*Again*

Merit must be complete, conduct must be complete.

chunks.original_text: 修炼身中子母圆。 何愁性不圆。 喜团圆，十分圆。 云水风邀月正圆。 无分昼夜圆。 又 遇重阳，梦纯阳。 爇起心香礼正阳。 三师助我阳。 炼阴阳，固元阳。 五色霞光簇太阳。 云中子抱阳。 又 酒初醒，梦初惊。 幻化何须恋利名。 灰心远世情。 月初明，性初平。 倒泝清流过玉京。 黄芽渐渐荣。 又 屋贪多，地贪多。 不若灰心厌事多。 崇真利益多。 天如何，地如何。 富贵荣华待若何。 轮回奈我何。 以赠魏害风 害风仙，害风仙。 万事俱忘理太玄。 调和汞与铅。 结金莲，结金莲。 九转功成性月圆。 超凡入洞天。 赠零口权先生 出家儿，处无为。 至死如同初出时。 何愁道不知。 内慈悲，外憨痴。 绝虑忘机无执迷。 刀圭有分携。 又 朝清清，暮清清。
chunks.translated_text:
Cultivating the child and mother within the body to perfection,
What worry remains that the nature will not be whole?
Rejoicing in wholeness, utterly whole,
Clouds and water, wind and moon—all perfectly round.
Undivided, day and night are whole.

*Again*

Meeting Chongyang, dreaming of Chunyang,
Igniting the incense of the heart to worship Zhengyang.
The Three Masters aid my yang.

Refining yin and yang, securing primordial yang,
Five-colored radiance clusters around the sun.
Amid the clouds, the Master embraces yang.

*Again*

Wine barely sobered, dreams just startled,
Why cling to illusions of profit and fame?
Ashen-hearted, far from worldly cares.

Moon newly bright, nature newly serene,
Reversing the flow of clear streams past Jade Capital.
The yellow sprout gradually flourishes.

*Again*

Households covet much, lands covet much,
Better to be ashen-hearted, weary of worldly affairs.
Exalting the true brings manifold blessings.

Heaven—what of it? Earth—what of it?
Wealth, honor, glory—what awaits?
The wheel of rebirth—what can it do to me?

*For Wei Haifeng*

Haifeng the Immortal, Haifeng the Immortal,
All matters forgotten, pondering the Great Mystery.
Harmonizing mercury and lead.

Binding golden lotuses, binding golden lotuses,
Ninefold refinement complete, the moon of nature whole.
Transcending the mortal to enter the grotto-heaven.

*For Master Quan of Lingkou*

A child of the household, dwelling in non-action,
Even unto death, as at the first emergence.
What worry that the Dao remains unknown?

Within—compassion; without—foolish simplicity,
Cutting off cares, forgetting schemes, free from delusion.
The elixir’s measure is within grasp.

*Again*

Dawn—so clear, so clear,
Dusk—so clear, so clear.

chunks.original_text: 清净清闲清净清。 清清清更清。 抱灵灵，固灵灵。 灵显灵明灵显灵。 灵灵灵更灵。 又 垒浮图，垒浮图。 悟彻浮生恶假躯。 回头认本初。 莫踌蹰，莫踌蹰。 急急修完无价珠。 功成蓬岛居。 赠众女姑 女姑听，女姑听。 学取麻姑至净清。 依他妙善行。 莫惺惺，莫惺惺。 外做憨痴内自灵。 功成赴玉京。 赠六曲杜丁李张三道友 休哀人，休哀人。 急急灰心哀自身。 回头结善因。 早搜真，早搜真。 营养身中神内神。 功成礼洞宾。 望蓬莱（望江南）十七首 首化姚玹 破故纸，缀袄可防风。 坐卧不愁寒水石，雪中敢采麦门冬。 从此得苁蓉。 浪荡子，常有自然铜。 鼎内朱砂烹炼就，天仙子入白云中。 蝉壳显山侗。 又
chunks.translated_text:
Stillness pure, leisure pure, stillness pure,
Pure—pure—ever purer.
Embracing the numinous, securing the numinous,
Numinous revealed, numinous luminous, numinous revealed,
Numinous—numinous—ever more numinous.

*Again*

Stacking the stupa, stacking the stupa,
Awakened to the floating life’s false body of evil.
Turn back to recognize the original beginning.

No hesitation, no hesitation,
Hasten to refine the priceless pearl.
Work complete, dwell on Penglai Isle.

*For the Many Female Daoists*

Female Daoists, listen, female Daoists, listen,
Learn from Ma Gu’s utmost purity and stillness,
Follow her wondrous and virtuous practice.

No pretence, no pretence,
Outwardly feign foolishness, inwardly remain numinous.
Work complete, ascend to the Jade Capital.

*For the Six Friends of the Sixth Bend: Du, Ding, Li, and Zhang*

Cease mourning others, cease mourning others,
Hasten to extinguish the heart’s sorrow for the self,
Turn back to weave good causes.

Seek the true early, seek the true early,
Nurture the spirit within the body’s inner spirit.
Work complete, pay homage to Master Dongbin.

*Gazing Toward Penglai (To the Tune of "Gazing Toward the River")*
Seventeen Poems
*First: Transforming Yao Xuan*

Breaking old paper, stitching a lined robe to ward off wind,
Sitting or lying, no fear of cold water-stone,
Daring to gather ophiopogon in the snow.
From this, obtain cistanche.

The dissolute youth,
Ever possesses natural copper.
Within the crucible, cinnabar refined to perfection,
The seed of celestial immortals enters the white clouds,
The cicada’s husk reveals Shan Tong.¹

*Again*

---
¹ *Shan Tong* (山侗): A reference to the Daoist adept Lu Dongbin in his reclusive aspect.

chunks.original_text: 马风子，独自赏元宵。 剔正命灯胜白昼，放开心月透青霄。 掌握紫芝苗。 金童舞，玉女更吹箫。 酒饮琼浆虽是美，有些闲事不逍遥。 惟恨少知交。 又 马风子，因遇弃荣华。 乞觅残余为活计，真清真净做生涯。 烹炼白朱砂。 人莫笑，一志实堪夸。 大道朝闻甘夕死，冰清玉洁绝纤瑕。 不敢辱师家。 又 马风子，昔日在迷津。 寻个出期终没计，欲知山上路儿真。 须问去来人。 风仙至，端的话良因。 指我一条真捷径，无差无错越红尘。 昼夜感师恩。 又 马风子，忽想在家时。 火院熬煎无限苦，心惊胆颤哭声悲。 悔恨出离迟。 号咷罢，感谢我真师。
chunks.translated_text:
Ma Fengzi, alone savoring the Lantern Festival,
Trims the life-lamp bright as day,
Lets the moon of the heart shine through the azure sky,
Holds the sprouts of purple mushrooms in hand.

Golden youths dance,
Jade maidens play their flutes.
Though the wine of jade nectar is fine,
Some idle matters still hinder freedom—
Only regret the lack of true friends.

*Again*

Ma Fengzi, having met with the renunciation of glory,
Begs for scraps to sustain himself,
Living a life of true purity.
Refining white cinnabar.

Let none mock him—
His single-minded resolve is truly praiseworthy.
To hear the Great Dao at dawn and die content by dusk,
Pure as ice and jade, flawless,
He dares not disgrace his master’s house.

*Again*

Ma Fengzi, once lost in the ford of delusion,
Sought an exit but found no way,
Longing to know the true path up the mountain—
One must ask those who have come and gone.

The Immortal of the Wind arrives,
Speaking of good causes in earnest.
Pointing out a true shortcut,
Without error, he transcends the red dust.
Day and night, he feels his master’s grace.

*Again*

Ma Fengzi, suddenly recalling his time at home,
Enduring endless suffering in the fiery household,
Heart trembling, gall quaking, weeping in sorrow,
Regretting his late departure.

After wailing,
He gives thanks to his true master.
chunks.overlap_context:
sforming Yao Xuan*

Breaking old paper, stitching a lined robe to ward off wind,
Sitting or lying, no fear of cold water-stone,
Daring to gather ophiopogon in the snow.
From this, obtain cistanche.

The dissolute youth,
Ever possesses natural copper.
Within the crucible, cinnabar refined to perfection,
The seed of celestial immortals enters the white clouds,
The cicada’s husk reveals Shan Tong.¹

*Again*

---
¹ *Shan Tong* (山侗): A reference to the Daoist adept Lu Dongbin in his reclusive aspect.

chunks.original_text: 钓出凡笼修不二，逍遥自在处玄机。 有分看瑶池。 闻蝉 秋蝉噪，声细又声长。 饮露食餐声不困，声声都了显行藏。 使我起凄惶。 堪嗟叹，模样是蜣螂。 尚自超然蝉蜕去，为人宁忍昧三光。 急急养铅霜。 八日 来朝九，今日访龙山。 预赏黄花先落帽，免教郑谷叹多端。 终要久长难。 马风子，别话一般般。 性结重阳花馥郁，万年千载不凋残。 永永有余欢。 九日吟 酬佳节，争赏菊花忙。 尽说陶潜深得趣，孟嘉落帽兴偏长。 终久落空亡。 马风子，别有好风光。 阳裹养阳阳养处，木牛牵向牧牛场。 永永庆重阳。 十日吟
chunks.translated_text:
Reeling from the mundane cage to cultivate the Non-Dual,
Carefree and at ease, dwelling in the mystery’s subtlety.
By fate, one gazes upon the Jasper Pool.

Hearing the cicada—
Autumn cicadas clamor, their voices faint yet long.
Drinking dew and feeding on air, their song never wearies,
Each cry revealing the hidden and manifest.
This stirs in me a deep disquiet.

Alas!
In form, they resemble dung beetles,
Yet transcendently shed their shells like cicadas—
How can man bear to obscure the Three Lights?
Hasten to nurture the lead and frost.

The eighth day—
Tomorrow the ninth, today I visit Dragon Mountain.
Anticipating the chrysanthemums, I let my hat fall first,
Spared from Zheng Gu’s myriad lamentations.
Yet in the end, lasting long proves difficult.

Ma Fengzi,
Speaks of matters one by one:
The nature binds to Double Yang, its blossoms fragrant,
Unwithering for ten thousand years and a thousand ages.
Everlasting, joy abounds.

Ninth Day Chant
In celebration of the fine festival, all vie to admire the chrysanthemums.
They say Tao Qian deeply grasped its charm,
Meng Jia’s hat fell, his delight unbounded—
Yet in the end, all falls to emptiness and decay.

Ma Fengzi,
Knows another splendid scene:
Within yang, nurture yang—where yang is fostered,
The Wooden Ox leads to the pasture of the Ox.
Everlasting, Double Yang is celebrated.

Tenth Day Chant

chunks.original_text: 今朝菊，人见意阑珊。 祇是秋香经一夜，致令郑谷叹多端。 终要久长难。 马风子，别有一般般。 万顷白云知去处，金莲花朵不教残。 永永道人欢。 又 寻大道，不在路迢迢。 云水清闲真自在，姹婴相伴做逍遥。 此理有谁消。 马风子，悟彻十分乔。 两脚轻狂街上舞，往来独许弄风飙。 明月杖头挑。 道友修庵 丘与马，入道绝贪求。 欲报师恩常念念，三年守服岂能休。 何处好藏头。 旧居址，深谢许同修。 但愿我公同我志，同心同德做同流。 同步访瀛洲。 又 外颠倒，爱欲似冤雠。 富贵荣华都不顾，人情浓处急抽头。 物外做持修。 内颠倒，真火戏清流。 六月降霜麻麦秀，三冬时雨润丹丘。 云步访瀛洲。 又
chunks.translated_text:
This morning’s chrysanthemums,
People see them fading in intent.
Their autumn fragrance lingers but a night—
Enough to draw Zheng Gu’s myriad lamentations.
Yet in the end, lasting long proves difficult.

Ma Fengzi,
Speaks of matters one by one:
Ten thousand acres of white clouds know their place,
Golden lotus blossoms never allowed to wither.
Everlasting, the Daoist’s joy abounds.

Again
Seeking the Great Dao,
Not on distant, winding roads.
Amid cloud and water, at ease and truly free,
With the Mysterious Maiden and Infant as companions, roaming carefree.
Who can fathom this principle?

Ma Fengzi,
Has awakened fully to the lofty truth:
His two feet dance wildly in the streets,
Coming and going, only he is permitted to ride the whirlwind.
The bright moon is borne aloft on his staff.

Daoist Friends Build a Hermitage
Qiu and Ma,
Enter the Dao, forsaking all greed and seeking.
To repay their master’s kindness, they constantly bear it in mind,
Three years of mourning—how could it ever cease?
Where is a good place to hide one’s head?

The old dwelling site,
Deep gratitude to the fellow cultivator who permitted it.
Only wishing that my lord shares my aspiration,
With one heart and one virtue, we become one stream.
Together we seek Penglai.

Again
Outward inversion:
Love and desire like bitter enemies.
Wealth and honor, glory and splendor—all disregarded,
Where human attachments run deep, swiftly withdraw.
Beyond the material world, cultivate and uphold.

Inward inversion:
True fire plays with the clear stream.
In the sixth month, frost descends, hemp and wheat flourish,
In the three winters, timely rain nourishes the cinnabar mounds.
Cloud-borne steps seek Penglai.

chunks.original_text: 修大道，何必住深山。 混俗和光都看破，万千尘冗不相干。 别有一般般。 马风子，闲裹更寻闲。 见个木牛哮吼走，路逢石女笑痴顽。 喝去入长安。 又 马风子，业障武愚顽。 不认洞天真供养，却迷俗礼假修完。 心意怎清闲。 着外境，欲要塑师颜。 建塔修堂并立石，不思施主出钱难。 罪业积成山。 又 马风子，创置屋三间。 动土兴工经一载，杀伤蝼蚁命须还。 死堕鬼门关。 错中错，追悔亦应难。 造下业缘须受苦，刀山剑树定跻攀。 怎得列仙班。 罗公上树隔环墙乞词 马风子，不悟坏修行。 虽在环墙居处稳，诗词引出假声名。 惹得不安宁。 夸伶俐，却是不惺惺。 自愧隐身身不密，空成潦倒白头生。 怎得赴蓬瀛。 春日鄠县道友索 真消息，律管定春期。 应候土牛先击碎，芒儿闲散独何之。 此理有谁知。 马风子，凭仗做修持。 恰到人牛俱不见，澄澄湛湛入无为。 正是月明时。 西江月三十四首 自勉 识破家缘冤苦，忻然跳出乡闾。 秦川秀处作庵居，永住永住永住。 物外逍遥自在，如今寄甚家书。 还乡便得赴仙都，不去不去不去。 长安运同惠道袍 昨日道袍破敝，今朝便着新衣。 有人问我这因依，且显同知厚惠。 又恐着他华丽，弃之更不生疑。 道家蓑笠最相宜，贫后安眠稳睡。 又 心内常搜己过，口中不说他非。
chunks.translated_text:
To cultivate the Great Dao, why dwell in deep mountains?
Amid the mundane, blending light—all seen through,
Myriad worldly trivia leave no trace.
There is another realm, another state.

Ma Fengzi,
In leisure seeks more leisure still.
He sees a wooden ox roaring past,
Meets a stone maiden laughing, foolish and dull.
With a shout, he enters Chang’an.

Again
Ma Fengzi,
Karmic hindrance—stubborn and dull.
Fails to recognize the true offering of grotto-heavens,
But deludes himself with worldly rites, false completion.
How can his heart and mind be at ease?

Bound by external realms,
He desires to mold his master’s visage.
Building pagodas, halls, and erecting steles,
Heedless of the donor’s hardship in giving.
Sin and karma pile like mountains.

Again
Ma Fengzi,
Constructs three rooms for a hut.
Breaking ground, a year of labor,
Slaughtering ants—lives must be repaid.
Death leads to the gates of hell.

Mistake upon mistake,
Even regret comes too late.
The karma he forged must be endured,
Scaling mountains of knives and forests of swords.
How then to join the ranks of immortals?

Luo Gong climbs a tree beyond the walled garden to beg for verses
Ma Fengzi,
Fails to awaken, corrupts his practice.
Though secure within the walled garden,
Poetry and lyrics draw false renown,
Stirring unrest and unease.

Boasting cleverness,
Yet truly unwise.
Ashamed, his hidden self not concealed,
Wasting away, his hair turns white in vain.
How then to reach Penglai?

Spring day, a fellow cultivator in Hu County requests
The true message:
The pitch-pipe sets the spring’s arrival.
As the earth-ox is struck in season,
Where do the idle sprouts wander alone?
Who understands this principle?

Ma Fengzi,
Relies on steadfast cultivation.
Just when both ox and man vanish,
Limpid and still, he enters non-action.
This is the time of bright moonlight.

*Xijiangyue*, Thirty-Four Poems
**Self-Exhortation**

Seeing through the bitterness of family entanglements,
Joyfully leaping beyond the village gate.
In the beauty of Qin Chuan, I make my hermitage,
To dwell forever, forever, forever.

Beyond the material, carefree and at ease,
Now what need is there to send word home?
Returning, I would ascend to the immortal capital—
No, I will not go, not go, not go.

**To Fellow Cultivator Yun in Chang’an, Who Gifted a Daoist Robe**
Yesterday’s robe was tattered and worn,
Today I don this new attire.
If asked the reason why,
I show the kindness of a fellow cultivator’s gift.

Yet fearing its splendor,
I cast it aside, no doubt arising.
A Daoist’s straw cloak and bamboo hat suit best,
After poverty, sound sleep comes easily.

Again
Within the heart, constantly examine one’s faults,
From the mouth, never speak ill of others.

chunks.original_text: 世人为处我无为，乞食街前不耻。 日日饱餐玉蕊，时时烂饮刀圭。 一朝引出化生儿，方显道家活计。 赠吴知纲 学道休妻别子，气财酒色捐除。 攀缘爱念永教无，绝尽忧愁思虑。 不得无明暂起，逍遥物外闲居。 常清常净是功夫，相称全真门户。 又 学道休迷导引，不宜修饰容仪。 相违世俗处无为，生计水云无击。 功行修持何幸，施为杀了三尸。 一灵性月越瑶池，奇异方知容易。 赠清净散人 一则降心灭意，二当绝虑忘机。 三须戒说是和非，四莫尘情暂起。 五便完全神气，六持无作无为。 七教功行两无亏，八得超凡出世。 赠明月散人 一道经花玉线，二轮日月烹煎。 三车搬运入丹田，四海云游走遍。 五色霞光出现，六情变作青莲。 七真攒聚性圆圆，八臂金刚伏善。 又 地肺重阳师父，吕公专遣云游。 秘玄隐奥访东牟，钓我夫妻两口。 十化分梨匠手，百朝锁户机谋。 千篇诗曲拽回头，万劫同杯仙酒。 又 不耻蓬头垢面，不嫌粝食粗衣。 不惭求乞做贫儿，不羡荣华富贵。 一日功成行满，仙裳天赐威仪。 星冠月帔履云归，节步玎珰玉佩。 又 人总贪生尽死，我今认死长生。 这般径路少人行，悟后舍家勇猛。 休说玄元难解，我观容易分明。 要君守拙绝多能，天地悉归清静。 赠安静散人俱守极 休要寻龙寻虎，不须搜姹搜婴。 勿劳讲论汞铅精，尽是虚名惑恁。 只要心中清静，无为便是功成。 慈悲相助气神凝，如此神仙有准。 又 大道都来六字，自然清静无为。 有人依得合希夷，视听何须眼耳。 清静内容欢喜，无为功就神飞。 自然云步赴瑶池，三岛十洲仙会。 又 莫论离龙坎虎，休言赤髓黄芽。 勿谈搬运紫河车，不说婴娇女姹。 绝虑忘机最妙，澄神养浩尤佳。 无为无作路无差，豁达灵根无价。 又 守拙宜乎宁耐，曾分秀气三台。 龙吟虎啸去还来，明月清风自在。 五道霞光覆载，神珠养就辞胎。 一声霹雳洞门开，始觉山侗奇怪。 赠任守－ 一不轻师慢法，二遵清静仙经。 三存精气养神灵，四把尘劳拂尽。 五戒无明业火，六除俗礼人情。 七擒猿马永安宁，八味琼浆得饮。 又 江畔溪边雪裹，阴阳造化希奇。 黄芽瑞草出幽微，别是一般香美。 用玉轻轻研细，烹煎神水相宜。 山侗啜罢赴瑶池，不让卢仝知味。 又 海岛丘刘谭马，因师各弃荣华。 逍遥自在乐无涯，休论高高下下。 不会琴棋书画，些儿营运无差。 眠云卧月饮流霞，醉后惺惺洒洒。 又 是是非非远远，尘尘冗冗捐捐。
chunks.translated_text:
The world pursues, I practice non-action,
Begging for food in the streets without shame.
Daily I feast on jade petals,
Hourly I drink deeply of the elixir knife.
One day I’ll lead forth my transformed child—
Then the Daoist livelihood shall truly appear.

**To Wu Zhigang**
Leave behind wife and children to study the Dao,
Abandon qi, wealth, wine, and lust.
Let attachments and affections forever cease,
Cutting off all sorrow and anxiety.
Let no delusion briefly arise,
Roam carefree beyond the material world.
Constant purity, constant stillness—this is the work,
Fitting the gate of Perfect Realization.

**Again**
Studying the Dao, do not be misled by guiding and pulling,
Nor should you adorn your appearance.
Oppose worldly customs with non-action,
Your livelihood like water and clouds, untroubled.
How fortunate is the cultivation of merit and conduct,
Your actions slaying the Three Worms.
The spirit-moon of your singular soul crosses Jade Pool—
Only then will you know the ease of the extraordinary.

**To the Pure and Unattached One**
First, subdue the heart and extinguish intent,
Second, cut off thoughts and forget scheming.
Third, refrain from speaking of right and wrong,
Fourth, let no worldly passions briefly arise.
Fifth, perfect spirit and qi,
Sixth, uphold non-doing and non-action.
Seventh, let merit and conduct never falter,
Eighth, transcend the mundane and leave the world.

**To the Bright Moon Unattached One**
One strand of scripture, a jade-threaded flower,
Two wheels of sun and moon refine and boil.
Three carts transport into the cinnabar field,
Four seas traversed in cloud-wandering.
Five-colored rosy clouds appear,
The six senses transformed into blue lotuses.
The Seven Perfected gather, the nature round,
Eight-armed vajras subdue goodness.

**Again**
Master Chongyang of Earth’s Lung,
Lord Lü specially sent to wander the clouds.
Seeking hidden mysteries in secret depths, visiting Dongmou,
Hooking us, husband and wife.
Ten transformations, the pear-dividing craftsman’s hand,
A hundred mornings, the locked-door scheme.
A thousand poems and songs turn the head back,
Ten thousand kalpas share the immortal’s cup of wine.

**Again**
Unashamed of disheveled hair and grimy face,
Unbothered by coarse food and rough clothes.
Unabashed to beg as a poor child,
Unenvious of glory and wealth.
One day, merit complete and conduct fulfilled,
Heaven bestows immortal robes and majestic bearing.
Star-crown and moon-cape, stepping on clouds to return,
Jade pendants chiming with each measured step.

**Again**
People all cling to life and fear death,
I now recognize death to attain eternal life.
Few walk this path,
After awakening, boldly leave home.
Do not say the Mystery and Origin are hard to grasp—
I see them clearly and easily.
Bid you guard simplicity and shun excess skill,
Heaven and earth all return to purity and stillness.

**To the Tranquil and Unattached One, Ju Shouji**
No need to seek dragon or tiger,
Nor search for the maiden or infant.
Do not labor over discussions of mercury and lead,
All are empty names that delude you.
Only keep the heart pure and still,
Non-action is the accomplishment of merit.
Compassion aids in condensing qi and spirit—
Thus, the attainment of immortality is certain.

**Again**
The Great Dao comes down to six words:
Naturally pure, still, and non-active.
One who can follow this meets the subtle and tranquil,
What need for eyes and ears in seeing and hearing?
Within purity and stillness, joy arises,
Non-action’s merit completes the soaring spirit.
Naturally step on clouds to Jade Pool,
The immortal assembly of the Three Islands and Ten Continents.

**Again**
Speak not of departing dragon or blocking tiger,
Nor mention red marrow or yellow sprouts.
Do not discuss transporting the purple river chariot,
Nor speak of the infant, maiden, or crone.
Cutting off thoughts and forgetting scheming is finest,
Calming the spirit and nurturing vastness is best.
Non-doing, non-action—no path goes astray,
The enlightened root is priceless in its openness.

**Again**
Guard simplicity with patience,
Once allotted the refined qi of the Three Terraces.
Dragon’s roar and tiger’s howl come and go,
Bright moon and clear wind, carefree.
Fivefold rosy light covers and bears,
The spirit-pearl nurtured, departing the womb.
A single thunderclap, the cavern gate opens—
Only then does the mountain rustic find it strange.

**To Ren Shouyi**
First, do not slight the master or disdain the dharma,
Second, follow the pure and still immortal scriptures.
Third, preserve essence and qi to nourish the spirit,
Fourth, brush away all worldly toil.
Fifth, extinguish the karmic fire of ignorance,
Sixth, remove worldly rites and human sentiments.
Seventh, capture the monkey and horse to forever secure peace,
Eighth, taste the jade nectar’s flavor.

**Again**
By rivers and streams, snow enfolds,
Yin and yang’s workings wondrously rare.
Yellow sprouts, auspicious herbs emerge from the subtle,
A different kind of fragrance and beauty.
Gently grind with jade,
Refine with divine water, fitting.
After the mountain rustic sips, he ascends to Jade Pool,
Not conceding to Lu Tong in knowing the taste.

**Again**
Island hermits Qiu, Liu, Tan, and Ma,
For their masters, each abandoned glory.
Carefree and at ease, boundless joy,
No talk of high or low.
Unversed in zither, chess, calligraphy, or painting,
A bit of livelihood, no error.
Sleeping in clouds, lying under the moon, drinking rosy mist,
After drunkenness, clear and free.

**Again**
Far, far from right and wrong,
Cast off, cast off all dust and clutter.
chunks.overlap_context:
No, I will not go, not go, not go.

**To Fellow Cultivator Yun in Chang’an, Who Gifted a Daoist Robe**
Yesterday’s robe was tattered and worn,
Today I don this new attire.
If asked the reason why,
I show the kindness of a fellow cultivator’s gift.

Yet fearing its splendor,
I cast it aside, no doubt arising.
A Daoist’s straw cloak and bamboo hat suit best,
After poverty, sound sleep comes easily.

Again
Within the heart, constantly examine one’s faults,
From the mouth, never speak ill of others.

chunks.original_text: 人人肯肯解冤冤，步步湾湾浅浅。 善善常常恋恋，玄玄永永绵绵。 明明了了这圆圆，杳杳冥冥显显。 又 物物般般认认，常常战战兢兢。 心心念念恐沉沉，得得来来损损。 日日清清净净，时时湛湛澄澄。 惺惺洒洒这灵灵，灿灿辉辉永永。 又 莫讶马风厮哄，人情且要和同。 至於行步敢从容，踏地仍怀恐痛。 无作无为妙用，常清常净真功。 住行坐外逐王风，岂敢心猿内动。 劝刘先生夫妇 欲继许君庞老，扪心自忖须知。 同心同德做修持，稍有相违远离。 三个不如两个，两人谈是谈非。 孤云野鹤任东西，岂有纤毫萦系。 又 尽说仙家饮酒，仙家不饮糟浆。 自然玉液味偏长，浇溉黄芽荣旺。 月下风前清爽，荐杯玉蕊馨香。 醉经饱德访蓬庄，高卧仙宫方丈。 又 学道腥膻不戒，明知断了慈悲。 五辛爽口欲滋基，怎比米精麦髓。 二物包藏秀气，吾门啖素相宜。 修持功行稍相亏，怎得长生久视。 又 莫论心肝肾肺，休搜南北东西。 勿言震兑坎和离，别有些儿奥旨。 吸尽江河淮济，星辰日月辉辉。 精神气血赴丹池，便得超凡出世。 又 运用无时不可，悟来有甚羞惭。 前三三与后三三，欲漏天机未敢。 顾我完全玉性，劝人省悟银蚕。 好归物外访玄谈，认个不增不减。 赠姚守清李守静 学道须离火院，搜玄参访良缘。 守清守静绝般般，乞觅於身大便。 云水须明内外，牢擒意马心猿。 万缘不着得神全，酬了修行大愿。 赠觉先生 心坐胜如打坐，心灰自没心猿。 形如槁木自安然，物外般般怎染。 养气勿劳呼吸，颐神全在抽添。 云房深处永绵绵，产个胎仙出现。 赠孙先生 学道完全性命，养身乞觅残余。 真功清净证元初，真行救人疾苦。 此外并无作做，心同毂食鹑居。 逍遥自在恰如愚，应过三清仙举。 赴胡公斋 我会调和美膳，自然入口甘甜。 不须酱醋与椒盐，一遍香如一遍。 满满将来不浅，那人吃了重添。 虚心实腹固根元，饱后云游仙院。 赠段知一 道隐身披布素，心慈口远肥甘。 逍遥物外住云庵，昔日作为岂敢。 伶俐番成懵懂，惺惺变作憨憨。 段公休说不悭贪，广占云烟似唵。 又 卧化胜如坐化，修行所贵真常。 假躯难以做馨香，何必临归着相。 说破飞升一着，成仙秖是神光。 天宫无用臭皮囊，携去深山掉样。 又 我欲只言清争，恐人入道徘徊。 阐扬龙虎去还来，初地多便奇怪。 我倦论持婴姹，恐人别意胡猜。 谁知男子产婴孩，回首自然悟解。 赠古知观藏头 □貌先生姓古，□中不讲之乎。 □壬妙处用功夫，□道是他省悟。 □亦玄门得趣，□飞玉兔金乌。 □君相伴化顽愚，□意如同数罟。 赠蔡悟真 □我石榴栗果，□金却要公猜。 □衣引个白衣来，□是人非不采。 □学非干大道，□元营养婴孩。 □端午正出君怀，□印何曾姓蔡。 凤栖梧二首 范蠡张良当日悟，得宠还惊，防患寻归路。 若恋功名尖险处，如何却得蓬庄住。 或问扶风缘甚去，京兆风仙，远远亲来度。 便觉灵明常有主，从今直入长生户。 又 物外逍遥修九九，慕乐清贫，寂净无中有。 不谒侯门常内守，脱离天地人三彀。 子午门封真卯酉，白虎青龙，对凤频哮吼。 佛面婴儿披锦绶，蓬瀛路上堪游走。 清心月 起念破清斋。
chunks.translated_text:
**Again**

Let each person willingly untie every grievance,
Step by step through gentle shallows.
Goodness ever cherished, lingering on,
Mystery forever unbroken, endless.

Bright and clear, this perfect round,
Vast and deep, yet manifest.

**Again**

Every thing, each kind, recognized in truth,
Ever trembling, ever vigilant.
Heart and thought, ever fearful of sinking,
Gains and losses, ever diminishing.

Day by day, pure and still,
Moment by moment, limpid and serene.
Awake and free, this numinous spirit,
Radiant and luminous, eternal.

**Again**

Marvel not at the clamor of horses and wind,
Let human feelings remain harmonious.
Even in walking, dare to be composed,
Treading the earth, yet mindful of its pain.

No action, no striving—subtle efficacy,
Ever pure, ever still—true attainment.
In standing, walking, sitting, follow the Kingly Wind,
How dare the mind-monkey stir within?

**Admonition to Master Liu and His Wife**

To follow Xu, Pang, and the ancients,
Search your hearts and know this well:
With one heart, one virtue, cultivate the Dao,
The slightest discord leads to separation.

Three are not as good as two,
Two may still debate right and wrong.
Like solitary clouds or wild cranes, drift east or west,
How could the slightest thread entangle you?

**Again**

Though immortals are said to drink wine,
They do not drink mere dregs.
Naturally, the jade nectar’s flavor lingers,
Nourishing the yellow sprout to flourish.

Beneath the moon, before the wind, refreshed,
Raising a cup of jade blossoms, fragrant.
Drunk on the scriptures, sated with virtue, visit Penglai’s estate,
Reclining high in the immortal’s chamber.

**Again**

Studying the Dao, yet clinging to rank flesh,
Knowing well it severs compassion.
The five pungents tantalize the palate, fostering desire,
How compare to the essence of rice and wheat?

These two hold the subtle qi,
In our gate, vegetarian fare is fitting.
If cultivation’s merit and conduct falter,
How attain long life and enduring vision?

**Again**

Speak not of heart, liver, spleen, or lungs,
Seek not north or south, east or west.
Mention not Zhen, Dui, Kan, or Li,
There lies another profound mystery.

Drawing in the rivers Huai and Ji,
The stars, sun, and moon shine bright.
Spirit, qi, and blood flow to the elixir pool,
Then transcend the mortal world.

**Again**

Practice knows no time unfit,
Enlightenment brings no shame.
The first three threes and the latter three threes—
I dare not leak the celestial secret.

I guard my flawless jade nature,
Urge others to awaken like silver silkworms.
Best to retreat beyond the world, seek profound discourse,
Recognize that which neither increases nor decreases.

**For Guard-Purity Yao and Guard-Stillness Li**

To study the Dao, leave the fiery household,
Seek the mysterious, visit good affinities.
Guard purity, guard stillness, abandon all,
Beg for the great convenience within the body.

Clouds and water must clarify inner and outer,
Firmly restrain the willful horse and mind-monkey.
Unattached to the myriad conditions, spirit complete,
Fulfill the great vow of cultivation.

**For Master Awareness**

Sitting in mind surpasses seated meditation,
When the mind is ash, the mind-monkey vanishes.
The body like withered wood, naturally at peace,
Beyond the world, how could anything stain it?

Nurture qi without laboring breath,
Preserve spirit through withdrawal and replenishment.
Deep in the cloud chamber, eternally continuous,
A fetal immortal emerges.

**For Master Sun**

Study the Dao to perfect life and destiny,
Nurture the body, beg for what remains.
True merit, pure and still, verifies the primordial beginning,
True conduct relieves the suffering of others.

Beyond this, nothing to be done,
The heart like a wheel’s hub or a quail’s nest.
Carefree and at ease, seemingly foolish,
Yet passing the Three Clarities’ immortal trials.

**Attending Lord Hu’s Vegetarian Feast**

I prepare harmonious delicacies,
Naturally sweet upon the tongue.
No need for soy, vinegar, pepper, or salt,
Each taste more fragrant than the last.

Filled to the brim, not shallow,
That person, having eaten, grows renewed.
Hollow the heart, fill the belly, strengthen the root,
After satiation, wander the immortal’s courts.

**For Duan Zhi-Yi**

The Dao concealed, clad in plain cloth,
Heart kind, mouth far from rich flavors.
Carefree beyond the world, dwelling in a cloud hut,
Dare not repeat past actions.

Cleverness turns to dullness,
Awareness transforms to simplicity.
Master Duan, speak not of stinginess,
Vastly occupying clouds and mist like *Om*.

**Again**

Lying transformation surpasses seated transformation,
In cultivation, true constancy is prized.
The borrowed body cannot become fragrant incense,
Why cling to form at the hour of return?

The secret of ascending revealed in one move,
Immortality is but the spirit’s light.
The celestial palace has no use for foul flesh,
Carry it to the deep mountains to discard.

**Again**

I wish to speak only of purity,
Lest others waver on the Dao’s path.
Expounding the dragon and tiger’s departure and return,
The initial stage is full of strangeness.

Weary of discussing the infant and maiden,
Lest others misconstrue with wild guesses.
Who knows the man may birth an infant?
Turning back, one naturally understands.

**For Master Gu of Hidden Wisdom**

□Gu, the master in appearance,
□Within, no talk of "this" or "that."
□In the subtle workings of Ren,
□The Dao is his awakening.

□Also delighting in the mysterious gate,
□Soaring with jade hare and golden crow.
□Accompanying you to transform the foolish,
□□Intent like a fishing net’s count.

**For Cai Wu-Zhen**

□My pomegranates and chestnuts,
□Yet you must guess the golden core.
□In plain robes, leading a white-robed one,
□□Disregarding right and wrong.

□Learning unrelated to the great Dao,
□□Nurturing the primordial infant.
□At the Dragon Boat Festival, you emerge from the womb,
□□How could the seal bear the surname Cai?

**Phoenix Perched on a Wutong Tree (Two Poems)**

Fan Li and Zhang Liang, awakened in their day,
Gained favor yet feared, sought retreat’s path.
If one clings to fame’s treacherous peak,
How could they dwell in Penglai’s estate?

Someone asked why I left the capital,
The Immortal of Fengxian came from afar to guide.
Suddenly, the numinous brightness has a master,
From now on, enter the gate of eternal life.

**Again**

Beyond the world, carefree, cultivating the nine nines,
Admiring joy in poverty, stillness within nothingness.
Not visiting noble gates, ever inward-turned,
Escaping the three snares of heaven, earth, and man.

Sealing the Zi-Wu gates, true Mao-You,
White tiger, green dragon, facing the phoenix’s roars.
The infant on the Buddha’s face wears brocade,
Worthy to wander Penglai’s immortal paths.

**Moon of Pure Heart**

A single thought breaks the pure fast.

chunks.translated_text:
**Craving Love Brings Disaster**

Craving love must bring disaster.
Why should numinous brightness part from the Three Terraces?
Stealing peaches—not just two or three times—
Thus banished, cast out from Penglai.
How could this compare to pillar-and-beam timber?
Would immortal essence ever suffer dust’s burial?
In the Great Luo Heaven, all is well arranged.
When the golden elixir’s nine cycles complete their work,
Once more I shall return—
Spared the wheel of rebirth.

**Drinking Cinnabar (Two *Shāoxī Sā* Poems, Third of Three)**

A heart of frost and snow, free of striving,
Naturally untouched by worldly dust.
Ever graceful, sleeves like clouds dance between twin forests.

Nine-turned cinnabar births purple mists,
A stream of white jade nurtures yellow gold.
Only regret the mountain recluse finds too few kindred spirits.

**Again**

Beyond the world, cultivating a garden beyond the world,
Probing mysteries, seeking wonders, discerning the root-source.
Firmly seize the monkey-mind and horse-will.

First gather tiger and dragon into the crucible,
Then lead mercury and lead back to their origin.
Spirit congeals, qi knits, nature rounds into wholeness.

**Passing Hanpi, a Daoist Friend Asks for a Poem**

Had I not wandered the clouds to reach Meipi,
How would I know this place hides a Jade Pool?
Each one wonders why I leave no verse behind.

Walls adorned with pearls, steles carved with jade,
Their radiance gleams, resplendent with lingering light.
Why need Ma Yu compose another poem?

**For Venerable Zhao**

chunks.translated_text:
**Teaching in Myriad Ways**

A thousand teachings, ten thousand methods—all to instruct,
Yet how to teach you to sever the dust from your heart?
Only upon awakening may you grasp the true cause.

Fear of death severs the bonds of love and desire,
Forgetting scheming, qi and spirit naturally pure.
Non-action, clarity—thus harmonizing with Heaven’s truth.

**Sent to Daoist Friends in Nanjing**

Ashamed I lack the karmic tie to visit Daliang,
Nor do I harbor the intent to emulate the worthy.
Yet I ponder the Daoist friends at Yimen Gate.

I, within the encircling walls, temper water and fire,
When will you gentlemen transcend the heat and cold?
Mountain recluse urges: awaken from the yellow millet dream.

**Recalling Hu Zijin of Wuwei Hermitage**

Among cloud companions, Hu Zijin of Zhongtiao,
His golden waves and jadelike ripples cleanse the heart.
To this day, his cloud-water robes remain.

Now reading the wondrous record of Wuwei Hermitage,
Each word within shines upon my lapels.
How can these lapels bear such radiant splendor?

**For Immortal Physician Zhao**

With single-minded devotion, he enters the mysteries, renouncing fame and profit,
Free of worldly affairs, his qi and spirit clear.
The Three Lights gather—everlasting peace.

Unbound by the four seasons, he embodies true creation,
Five-hued mists of radiance coalesce into form.
A six-zhu robe hangs as the crane comes to welcome him.

**Again, Thinking of Hu Zijin**

How fine is Lecturer Hu of Zhongtiao,
A scholar versed in Dao, enlightened to Chan’s subtleties,
Naturally attaining such understanding!

The stone maiden returns drunk to the golden tiger’s cave,
The iron ox plows into the fire-dragon’s pool.
The fetal immortal plucks the purple magic mushroom.
